title: 106_hr263
content: The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" imposes an excise tax on individuals acquiring structured settlement payments in factoring transactions, as outlined in Chapter 55 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" imposes a 50 percent tax on individuals acquiring structured settlement payment rights in factoring transactions, with exceptions for court-approved hardship cases. The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" allows for the transfer of structured settlement payments in cases of extraordinary, unanticipated, and imminent needs, as determined by a court or administrative authority. The term "structured settlement" refers to an arrangement for the periodic payment of damages that are excludable from the recipient's gross income. The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" permits the transfer of periodic compensation payments under workers' compensation acts that are excludable from gross income. The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" allows for the transfer of structured settlement payment rights, defined as rights to receive payments under a structured settlement, through structured settlement factoring transactions. The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" permits the transfer of structured settlement payment rights for consideration through various means such as sale, assignment, or pledge. The factoring discount is the difference between the total amount of structured settlement payments acquired and the actual amount paid by the acquirer. The term 'relevant court or administrative authority' refers to the court or administrative body with jurisdiction over the action resolved by the structured settlement. The relevant court or administrative authority with jurisdiction over the structured settlement claim may be based on the residence of the recipient. Structured settlement factoring transactions will not affect the application of certain provisions if the requirements of sections 72, 130, and 461(h) were met at the time of entering into the structured settlement. The transaction will not affect the application of certain provisions to the parties involved in the structured settlement. The Secretary is authorized to prescribe regulations for the treatment of amounts received in a structured settlement factoring transaction. Information reporting requirements are amended to include new regulations. "Reporting requirements for structured settlement factoring transactions are outlined in SEC. 6050T." "In structured settlement factoring transactions, the person making payments must provide returns and statements to the acquirer as per section 6041 or be subject to tax under section 5891." The person making structured settlement payments must provide returns and statements to the acquirer with notice and knowledge, as prescribed by the Secretary. This applies instead of other reporting provisions for structured settlement factoring transactions. The provisions of section 3405 do not apply to the person making structured settlement payments in a structured settlement factoring transaction. The term 'acquirer of the structured settlement payment rights' includes any person described in section 7701(a)(1). Clerical amendments are made to the table of chapters for subtitle E of the Code. Chapter 55 introduces reporting requirements for structured settlement factoring transactions under Sec. 6050T of the tax code. The amendments made by this section apply to structured settlement factoring transactions occurring after the date of enactment of this Act.
